newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY PRIVATE TV BIDS IN, SEPTEMBER START LIKELY.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY PRIVATE TV BIDS IN, SEPTEMBER START LIKELY.

text.p: Hungary's radio and television body ORTT said on Thursday it had received three bids for the two national commercial TV channels offered for 10-year concessions.

The bidders for Hungary's television market, which attracted $200 million in advertising fees last year, will only be announced once the validity of the bids has been established, an ORTT official said.
"We expect the checks to be done by the second half of next week," ORTT spokesman Gyorgy Lovas told Reuters.
He added that one bidder had bid for the first channel, one for the second, and a third for both channels.

Foreign companies said to be lining up to bid for the TV channels include U.S.- based Central European Media Enterprises , CLT-Bertelsmann , which owns RTL satellite television, a Hungarian-Swedish consortium MTM-SBS and a consortium of French channel TF1 and the German Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung.
The ORTT did not release the names of the bidders.
The minimum concession fee is eight billion forints per channel per year, plus VAT at 25 percent, three years payable in advance.
Only consortia were allowed to bid, no single company is allowed to have more than a 49 percent stake, while Hungarians have to hold a minimum of 26 percent.
Under Hungary's media law, bids have to be evaluated within 60 days and the winners have to go on air three months after the concession contracts have been signed.
Lovas said a September starting time is realistic.
He dismissed press reports that said the tender procedure was unfair and biased.

"The ORTT, despite imaginary or real political and other pressures, will only base its decision on the content of the bids, expert opinions and consultations with the European Media Institute," he said.
He added that the tender process for two national radio channels is also underway, and the ORTT would like to see the radio channels go live by October.
"The deadline seems tight, especially as the two radio cahnnels are not of equal value and at least six or seven groups have expressed interest so far," Lovas said.
